title: How to Use Tree Diagrams
text: When looking at a tree diagram, it consists of "branches", sometimes labeled with frequencies (whole numbers) or probabilities (fractions). Each branch of the tree represents a "choice" of sorts and each level represents the completion of a choice, and at the bottom of the tree--the leaf--houses the final outcomes. To get to the final outcome, you want to multiply all the probabilities going down the tree from the top to the end of the leaf.

title: Using the Tree Diagram
text: To find P(FF), that means we need to determine the number of possibilities to get to the outcome of FF divided by the total number of possible outcomes. How many possible ways are there to get to FF?

title: Using the Tree Diagram
text: To find P(FF), that means we need to determine the number of possibilities to get to the outcome of FF divided by the total number of possible outcomes. How many possible outcomes are there total?

title: Finding Probability
text: What is P(FF), or in other words, what is the number of possible ways to reach FF divided by the total number of possible outcomes?
